supporting_quotes: Nabiullina graduated from school No. 31 of Ufa, followed by the Moscow State University Faculty of Economics in 1986.
In subsequent years, she was selected for the 2007 Yale World Fellows program.

organizations: Russian Union of Industrialists and Entrepreneurs
supporting_quotes: Between 1991 and 1994, Nabiullina worked at the USSR Science and Industry Union and its successor, the Russian Union of Industrialists and Entrepreneurs.

organizations: Ministry for Economic Development and Trade
supporting_quotes: In 1994, she moved to the Ministry for Economic Development and Trade, where she rose to the level of deputy minister by 1997; she left the ministry in 1998.
She spent the next two years with Sberbank as its chief executive

She spent the next two years with Sberbank as its chief executive and with former Economic Development and Trade Minister German Gref's non-governmental think tank, the Center for Strategic Development

organizations: Ministry for Economic Development and Trade
supporting_quotes: before returning to the Ministry for Economic Development and Trade as first deputy in 2000.
Between 2003 and her September 2007 appointment as minister, she chaired the Center for Strategic Development
Between 2003 and her September 2007 appointment as minister, she chaired the Center for Strategic Development as well as an advisory committee preparing for Russia's 2006 presidency of the G8.

roles: Minister of Economic Development and Trade
supporting_quotes: Russian President Putin appointed Nabiullina to the post of minister of economic development and trade on 24 September 2007, replacing Gref.
remained in that position until 21 May 2012.

roles: 1st class Active State Councillor of the Russian Federation
supporting_quotes: She has the federal state civilian service rank of 1st class Active State Councillor of the Russian Federation.

organizations: Office of the President of Russia

supporting_quotes: From May 2012 to June 2013, she served as Assistant to President Putin for Economic Affairs.

roles: Governor of the Central Bank of Russia
supporting_quotes: Succeeding Sergey Ignatyev in 2013, Nabiullina was appointed head of the Central Bank of Russia
Assumed office 24 June 2013

roles: ranked among world's most powerful women
supporting_quotes: In May 2014 she was named one of the world's most powerful women by Forbes
As of 2019, she was listed as the 53rd most powerful woman in the world by Forbes.

roles: Central Bank Governor of the Year

roles: Central Banker of the Year, Europe
supporting_quotes: In 2017, the British magazine The Banker chose Nabiullina as 'Central Banker of the Year, Europe'.
On 19 April 2022, Nabiullina was sanctioned by Australia after the Russian invasion of Ukraine.
On 30 September 2022, after the Russian annexation of southern and eastern Ukraine, she was sanctioned by the United States.
In September 2022, the United States Treasury Department sanctioned Nabiullina.
